Sure, you can train any abilities. However, everything can't be trained: such as way of thinking. This is significant because certain ways of thinking are more predisposed for certain things, thus always allowing you to be inherently better.

It doesn't matter if you paint just as well as a world renowned artist, if you don't think as one would, if your way of comprehending the things around you is different.

Here is an example in story form:
Students are taking an very important standardized test to measure their "intelligence", we'll call this test the ACT. All the smart, hardworking students had done expectedly well on the ACT due to their constant training and practice for it. All the other students had also done expectedly less well thanks to less training. However, there's a problem. The highest score on the standardized test was not from one of the hardworking smart kids, it was from a slacker. He had managed to guess 33% of the ACT, yet achieved the highest score.

How?

Upon further investigation it was discovered that he simply was able to think about the test differently than all other students. He had solved the puzzle hidden in the structure of the questions that inadvertently always led to the correct answer.

Though that is an extreme example, it goes to show that not only natural ability or training, but the wielder's way of thinking can make them inherently better at certain things than others.

Talent in the colloquial sense does not exist. If your genetics are responsible for half of your potential then the whole Nurture vs. Nature debate becomes meaningless as they are equal parts of a whole. However, most people associate talent as an inborn "step-up-the-ladder" if you will. Which is not true. People that grow to master something do so with work alone. Being called talented by people is their way of giving up. They would rather chalk up your skill to something out of their control rather than force them self to take in interest in progression. When you suck at baseball but you love playing it so much that you never worry about how it feels to suck, then what you are doing is training. Most people respond to failure at an activity by quitting. Nobody likes to do something that doesn't feel rewarding. Talent is seeing the activity itself as the reward, no matter your skill level. Being that guy that would rather work on a drawing than go out with friends is no more talented than anyone else. But he is spending more total hours on the development of said skill than his peers.

I feel like some people are mixing up talent and potential. Talent would be when an individual is skilled at something that they have not necessarily devoted a large portion of time to. For example, if one has quick reflexes or is good with numbers and abstract thought then they might excel in something like table tennis or mathematics. They have a TALENT for that field because their traits (which have probably subconsciously been developed from an early age) allow them to succeed.

Potential is when one has the ability to grow their skill. An individual who has a more muscular frame and is taller may have great POTENTIAL due to their base line being so high already. This is where training comes in the realize that potential.

This is absolutely wrong. You see, I trained once with a friend of mine for running. This guy had talent and genetics, so he had beautiful body and was great at running. When I was running with him, the results were 300 meters of keeping up to him.
He did great, was running far faster than me, had a far higher stamina and everything for him was better. Later years I trained myself with the exact same exercise, running.
This time though I was running completely alone with my OWN pace. Super slow, but in the end I did all the course after a MONTH. It took me a full month to do what that previous exercise took the other guy a day to do. If I was to do it at his own PACE, it would have taken me MUCH MORE (It took me 3 months and absolutely no improvement at all).
So this exact same exercise showing on the video was adequate for those exact same people. If everybody was doing it at their own pace, everybody would have had same improvements for a period of time.
Later on I ran again with him and he got tired. I was like: "What? Are you kidding me?!". I was really amazed, but he actually could not keep up and was tired. He also said that he was doing that to stretch his muscles. He won 5th place in my country for 21km.
But guess what happened to me later on! I actually was smoking when I was training alone. It took me two months to achieve a stunning 7km! (for me it is stunning, from 0.3 to 7!)
So the genetics are just pre-written machine code for you, but you can change that if you really believe in yourself.

Even though some people will have the talent and will be naturally better than you when you start out with no effort at all, you can get up to and surpass their level with enough effort. Someone who has the talent and is naturally good at something may rise above the pack easily at first, but if they don't put in the effort they won't stay there, they'll be surpassed by people willing to put in the work whether they have the talent or not. However, people with the talent who are also willing to put as much work in to improve as the people who don't - THOSE are the people who become superstars. There is a fallacy of false cause in this video.

"Individuals who were related by blood saw similar improvements, indicating that their genetics played a role in their athletic potential."

1) The scientists that conducted this experiment can't conclude genetics plays a role in improvement, because genetics also play a role in disabilities as well. How do you compare an autistic child with his sibling that is normal functioning in an experiment like this?

2) Foster and adopted children weren't mentioned. Why didn't the scientists consider work ethic or upbringing into consideration.

3) It is unclear how improvement in training is measured between one sibling with extraordinary talent and the other sibling with zero talent?

The first thing that stuck out to me during this argument is that familial bonds effected the response to training. I think this could also be because habits within the family of course; such as diet and other activity related to habit building, and not necessarily genetics alone. So the argument for "Talent" alone really falls when you mention the idea "LUCK". That "one" is surrounded by positive stimuli or has more observation power than others. Then you can also argue that luck has nothing to do with it; since really all it is: is the contributing factors like diet, education, etc. So luck falls flat on just being a shallow, generalizing term for lamemens. You might beable to associate talent with genetic variation and epigenetics. Genetics can effect whether a person has longer arms, or blood vessels to transport more nutrients, or a trillion other mechanical features. But I will cast aside the idea that a person is born smart. Ironically they may be born Lucky since their habit building can be promoted by those mechanical features. Just don't stop short when arguing that talent has to do with luck, because then you're missing the point and squandering your genetic potential.

Here is something I would like to share: I started martial arts when I was 8, my instructor thought that I was a "low responder". I had a tough time picking up kicks and forms in particular. Hell, I couldn't even get my roundhouse kick over waist height. Yet now, as I am getting into XMA and tricking, kicks come really easy to me. I can get some in only a few attempts. Sound ironic, right? It all comes down to mind set for me, and this leads my opinion (relax, because it is only an opinion). See, maybe the individuals who were blood related and were "high responders" were simply siblings competing with each other to get good at athletic, or even mental feats. Also, a big (REALLY BIG) factor is simply confidence. If there is even the slightest hesitation or insecurity in your movement it shows up right away. Some of these so-called "low-responders" just have to let go of themselves and there self image in order to discover and unlock their potential. Finally, as for body types, yes there are different body types with different metabolisms and even natural muscle growth, however, as far as I can tell, the only difference between individuals and their ability due to their natural body type, is that they THINK they are strong. It's sad, but in my experience, endomorphs and ectomorphs in particular tend to have a difficult time really pushing themselves to their true limits, only because they have been told time and time again in movies, ads and school that they were simply born unable to be strong. Which, as they find out in varying degrees of time, is bogus. This is why I believe that in maintaining an internal locus of control, anyone can become anything. They just have to love it, and, to an extent, let go of themselves. Good luck in whatever you do!

This video basically describes my life on the topic of talent vs. training.

I am extremely talented at what I do and people always ask me why; "Why are you so much better at this than I am? You're younger than me and paint better than I can!" I have to remind them that I have been painting since I was 3 years old and they usually started painting in their 20's. Then they're all off on "Well you're just more talented than me and were born with talent because no one decides what they want to do with their life when they're 3-because I didn't." I have to remind them that I may have just been born more determined and more inclined to this type of life. But for the first 10 or more years of painting, my painting sucked. I got better at it through determination and hard work. You could do it too, but if you're not determined and don't want to, and aren't ready to spend the rest of your entire life working toward something, don't get mad when you don't get there.

I haven't watched the video yet, but this essentially the same thing as "Nature vs. Nurture." Talent = nature & training = nurture. Genetics determine at what rate you can develop, learn, etc and also set your upper limits of potential growth/development. Environment/nurture/training is what molds and shapes you. 

You can be born with the best genetics for everything. Literally perfect genes, but you have no food to eat or water to drink you will never make it past infancy. 

The other thing is.. we can understand, fully understand.. and control.. fully control NURTURE, training, environment... but we have a very limited understanding of genes and genetics. Even with all the science, research, discoveries, breakthroughs, etc in genetics research all it's left us with is more QUESTIONS then ANSWERS. DNA is elusive and cryptic... Environment/training is not. 

SO.. you cannot even answer the question, which is most important because we lack an even understanding of both... but you can say from a common sense perspective that obviously "training" is MORE important.. because like I said before.. without it you can never develop period.  USE IT OR LOSE IT. Period.

Talent and training are both important factors when it comes to succeeding in anything, although how they interact with each other tends to vary from one activity to the next.

Sports, for example, tend to require immense amounts of both talent and hard work. An appropriate build will often be just as important as keen judgement and strong muscles. Games of quick calculations can also require both training and talent, although it's not quite as clear that someone without talent can't simply keep up by training harder.

When it comes to succeeding in a career, I believe talent and training become interchangeable. When not directly competing for the top spot, in fact when there usually is no clearly defined top spot, talent and dedication are even less important than plain luck.

Many famous scientists did not become famous because they were the most brilliant scientists at the time, they simply were working on the right thing at the right time and were competent enough (through a mix of talent/work ethic) to get the job done. Businessmen, writers, musicians, actors, politicians- they could be the most skilled at what they do out there, but if they don't meet the right people and go into the right topics, they'll still get nowhere. Of course it takes very special circumstances for those with literally no talent to become successful, and with the modern class system being flexible enough for the dead weights at the top to sink to the bottom and the brilliant at the bottom to rise to the top, it's much less common. Inbred retards have become king in the past, but I believe we're past the point where that could happen.

This video is WAYYYY too oversimplified. That experiment isn't airtight enough to determine what it's trying to understand. If you take a group of random people and train them, that isn't going to determine if it's genetic or not because those people all have had different upbringings and experiences. That is NOT being factored into the experiment. Some subjects may have more experience with coordination than others so they're already at a head start. And the so-called family genes could be explained simply by the fact that the kids were raised by parents who exposed them to environmental factors that caused them to already be trained in certain areas of coordination. This video is misleading and should be taken down.

I think a lot of these comments seem to be missing the message of the video. What I got from this is that whether talent is better than training or vice versa doesn't matter, because the best athletes have talent and train very hard. There isn't an easy way to measure your own talent before you train, but by training, you can measure your progress up against your initial performance and determine both how talented you were initially and how well you respond to training.

To fit the athletic theme of these videos, talent vs. training is like a race, where the finish line is maximum personal ability and those who finish faster have more ability than those who finish slower. Talent is like having a head-start in this race, while training will increase speed and endurance in this race. While it's hard to measure whether having a head-start or having faster speed/endurance individually is better, it's important understand that the highest-level athletes taking first, second, etc. in this race both have a significant head-start AND insane speed/endurance.

In short, if you want to become a top athlete, you might need talent, but you can't rely on talent alone. You need to harness that talent with training. But this is not exclusive to athleticism. This is why people will pursue any walk of life in which they're naturally talented and receive some form of education or guidance over many years as training. This is how you increase your ability to do something, ANYthing.
